pullRequest.body:
two lemmas: `s.tsum (1:ENNReal) = s.encard` and `s.tsum c = s.encard * c`, where `c:ENNReal` and `s : Set Î±`.

---

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10320994534/job/28572825692)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10320994534/job/28572826002)
Thanks! There's some simplification we can do here. I tried to explain my thought process. Let me know if you have questions.

might as well just use `variable`
```suggestion
open Set Function

variable {Î± : Type*} (s : Set Î±)

```

I suggest adding the following `alias`. It's not absolutely necessary or anything, but I think we should have it:
```
alias â¨_, Set.encard_eq_topâ© := Set.encard_eq_top_iff
```
That being said, most of my suggestions relate to the finite case. Let me outline my changes for you with explanations:

1. This should be `simp` lemma.
2. I'm not sure why the `'` was present in the name, as there is no `ENNReal.tsum_one_eq` to distinguish it from. However, there *could* be (if we ever do away with `PartENat.card` and just use a currently non-existent `ENat.card`) which would sum over the whole type. That's why I added `set` to the name.
3. We generally don't use `if ... then ... else` in a proof. You could use `by_cases`, but, especially when you have to push a negation for common splits, I find it much more convenient to call the actual lemma, in this cases `Set.finite_or_infinite` with `obtain`.
4. `lift` is a great tactic. You must get to know it. To be honest, I didn't look at your proof of finiteness at all, except to say to myself, "that looks far too long for such an easy fact, surely we can do this more easily". Then I went hunting for a lemma that would allow me to convert that `tsum` into an actual finite sum (this is `tsum_fintype`), and for that I needed `Fintype â¥s`. That would be trivial if `s` were an actual `Finset Î±` instead of a `Set.Finite` term of `Set Î±`. That's exactly what the `lift` allows me to do!
5. you can just chain `rw`s on a single line.
```suggestion
@[simp]
lemma tsum_set_one_eq : â' (_ : s), (1 : ââ¥0â) = s.encard := by
  obtain (hfin | hinf) := Set.finite_or_infinite s
  Â· lift s to Finset Î± using hfin
    simp [tsum_fintype]
  Â· have : Infinite s := infinite_coe_iff.mpr hinf
    rw [tsum_const_eq_top_of_ne_zero one_ne_zero, encard_eq_top hinf, ENat.toENNReal_top]
```

Similar ideas, but note how we're now using the `simp` lemma from above
```suggestion
@[simp]
lemma tsum_set_const_eq (c : ââ¥0â) :
    â' (_ : s), (c : ââ¥0â) = s.encard * c := by
  rw [â one_mul c, ENNReal.tsum_mul_right]
  simp
```
i don't see how relying on a simp is better than only using rewrites in this case...
surely not having a simp makes the proof more robust?

In this particular case, it's not really a big deal, you can leave it how you had it if you prefer.

However, to answer your question, I would say two things:

1. Given the choice between say `rw [lem1, lem2, lem3, lem4, lem5]` and `simp`, I would greatly prefer the latter for readability and proof comprehension.
2. Given the same choice, I would again prefer `simp` (as a *closing* tactic only) for robustness, because it is not sensitive to changes in lemma names. Name changes are much more common than moving a given lemma into or out of the `simp` set.

In this case, I was opting for `simp` because it conveniently avoided the need to do an `nth_rw` (because even though it rewrites the rhs too, that gets `simp`ed away). But again, the proof you had here was fine.

```suggestion
This file provides lemmas relating sums of constants to the cardinality of the domain of these sums.

## TODO

+ Once we have a topology on `ENat`, provide an `ENat` valued version
+ Once we replace `PartENat` entirely with `ENat` (and get a `ENat.card` to replace `PartENat.card`), provide versions which sum over the whole type.
```

```suggestion
lemma tsum_set_const_eq (c : ââ¥0â) : â' (_:s), (c : ââ¥0â) = s.encard * c := by
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: add lemma relating Set.encard to tsum over ennreal
